The aide-de-camp is a crucial position in military leadership, responsible for assisting high-ranking officers in carrying out their duties. An ADC typically serves as a personal assistant to a commanding officer or a general, handling administrative and logistical duties, and relaying information between their principal and other staff members.

The training of an ADC may vary depending on the branch of the military they serve in. However, there are some common requirements, such as strong communication skills, attention to detail, and the ability to work under pressure.

In the United States Army, officers who are selected for ADC duty undergo a rigorous selection process and attend a specialized course at the US Army Command and General Staff College. The course covers a wide range of topics, including military history, leadership, communication skills, and protocol. Army ADCs also receive instruction on handling classified information, firearms safety, and tactical operations.

In the United States Marine Corps, ADCs receive training in the Marine Corps Officer Candidate School and attend the Basic Communications Officer Course. They also receive specialized training in the areas of protocol, military customs, and courtesies.

In the United States Navy, officers who serve as ADCs attend the Naval Postgraduate School's Executive Master of Business Administration Program. They also receive training in protocol and diplomatic etiquette.

In the United States Air Force, officers who serve as ADCs undergo a selection process and attend the Air Force Academy or Air War College. They also receive specialized training in protocol and are required to maintain a thorough understanding of the Air Force chain of command.

In general, training for ADCs in the military emphasizes the importance of communication, professionalism, and attention to detail. It varies depending on the branch of the military and the specific duties involved, but all ADCs are expected to be able to represent their commanding officer effectively and with the utmost professionalism.
